title: 114_hr2980
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Mayflower Commemorative Coin Act". It includes findings related to the Act. The Congress finds that the arrival of the Pilgrims in 1620 and the Mayflower Compact are significant in U.S. history. The General Society of Mayflower Descendants aims to educate the public about the Pilgrims' journey and legacy. A commemorative coin will honor this history. A commemorative coin will raise awareness of the Pilgrims' arrival and the Mayflower Compact. Proceeds from the coin's sale will support educational programs. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions, which will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the Pilgrims' arrival in 1620, with inscriptions including the mint date "2020" and the year "1620", along with words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the General Society of Mayflower Descendants, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in proof and uncirculated quality at a single United States Mint facility. The Secretary can only issue these coins to the public during a one-year period starting on January 1, 2020. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount.

SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins issued under this Act include surcharges: $35 per $5 gold coin and $10 per $1 silver coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the General Society of Mayflower Descendants for educational purposes. The Society will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may be included for any coin issuance in a calendar year if already issued without a surcharge. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to avoid exceeding the annual issuance limitation. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary will ensure that minting coins under this Act will not cost the US Government and no funds will be disbursed until all costs are recovered by the Treasury.
